从在子宫里开始，运气就在职业成功中发挥着重要但往往未被承认的作用。沃伦·巴菲特曾谈到，如果他出生在美国，并以在市场经济中获得回报的方式赢得了“卵巢彩票”。漂亮的外表与更高的薪水以及在招聘过程中被要求面试的更大机会相关。您遭受歧视的经历将反映您的出生环境。

职业生涯的早期中转站通常都是偶然的：比如说，一个特别鼓舞人心的老板，或者一个带领你走向意想不到但明确方向的任务。运气可以影响最理性的职业的道路。瓦萨学院的 Qi Ge 和汉密尔顿学院的 Stephen Wu 在 2022 年发表的一篇论文发现，名字难读的经济学家，包括少数族裔的经济学家，不太可能被安排从事学术工作或获得终身教职。

名字还可以通过其他方式对抗经济学家。斯坦福大学的 Liran Einav 和现就职于普林斯顿大学的 Leeat Yariv 进行的另一项研究发现，姓氏首字母较早的教师更有可能获得顶尖院系的终身教职，他们将此归因于这样一个事实：经济学论文的作者倾向于按字母顺序列出。

表现出色可能是因为运气，而不是天赋。在金融市场上，在一个时期表现出色的资产管理公司往往会在下一个时期失去光彩。被动投资的兴起反映了这样一个事实：很少有选股者能够持续跑赢大盘。石油工业的历史充满了意外发现的故事。科罗拉多矿业学院的 Alexei Milkov 和 William Navidi 最近发表的一篇论文发现，90% 的行业从业者认为运气会影响勘探项目的结果。作者对挪威大陆架 50 年的钻探分析得出结论，各个公司之间的成功率差异是随机的。

关于运气是否影响高管薪酬一直存在争论。伦敦商学院的 Martina Andreani 和 Lakshmanan Shivakumar 以及犹他大学的 Atif Ellahie 最近发表的一篇论文表明确实如此。学者们研究了 2017 年美国大幅企业减税的影响，这一事件导致基于过去交易且无法归因于管理者技能的企业产生大量一次性税收收益和损失。他们发现，受到较少审查的公司，意外之财越大，首席执行官的薪酬越高；税收损失似乎并没有影响他们的收入。幸运的事情。

正如有些人盲目相信功绩决定成功一样，人们也可能过于依赖机会的作用。首席执行官很可能会因为运气而获得回报，但要想跻身公司高层，就需要天赋和努力。尽管有些人认为企业家只是幸运的人，对风险有很大的兴趣，但技能确实很重要。哈佛大学的保罗·冈珀斯 (Paul Gompers) 及其合著者 2006 年发表的一篇论文表明，成功公司的创始人比之前失败的企业家在下一次创业中获得成功的机会更高。更好的技术和更多的专业知识减少了机会的作用；例如，石油勘探的平均成功率随着时间的推移而上升。

但如果运气在结果中发挥的作用确实比人们通常认为的更重要，那意味着什么呢？对于个人来说，这表明你应该增加机会对你有利的机会。创业加速器Y Combinator 的合作伙伴通过谈论增加“运气表面积”来鼓励创始人申请他们的项目：将自己置于可能被拒绝的境地是让运气有更多机会来袭的一种方式。

对运气所扮演的角色的认识也应该影响管理者的行为。投资组合思维削弱了运气的作用：米尔科夫和纳维迪指出，如果公司完成大量独立油井，在石油勘探中碰上好运的可能性就会增加。如果运气可能意味着错误的决定会带来好的结果，反之亦然，那么管理者应该学会根据过程和结果来评估计划的成功。

如果随着时间的推移，技能和运气之间的差异变得明显，那么就根据表现的一致性而不是一次性的高潮来奖励人们。巴菲特一开始可能有一点运气，但一生的投资成功表明他已经最大限度地利用了运气。 ■

印度的富豪统治似乎是一成不变的。在追踪此类事情的胡润百富榜编制的年度富豪榜上，前两名无一例外都是安巴尼家族和阿达尼家族。今年没有什么不同。穆克什·安巴尼（Mukesh Ambani）位居第一，拥有 980 亿美元的财富。他取代了竞争对手、去年的获胜者高塔姆·阿达尼 (Gautam Adani)，后者的财富达 580 亿美元。不过，排名较低的同行，故事是一个变化。

首先，印度超级富豪的队伍不断壮大。胡润的最新榜单确定了 1,319 名财富达 1.2 亿美元或以上的人（其入选基准）。比去年增加了 216 个。富裕的主要来源并不是您所认为的传统致富途径，例如工业、金融和信息技术。相反，它们是消费品、材料和医疗保健。仿制药制造商 Alkem Laboratories 帮助将 11 人列入名单，是所有公司中最多的。 Asian Paints 上涨了 10 只，Tube Investments of India 上涨了 8 只，该公司从生产自行车零件扩展到各种其他零部件，而 Pidilite Industries 则上涨了 7 只，一家粘合剂制造商。

印度财富的人口结构和地理分布也在扩大。送货公司 Zepto 的 20 岁创始人首次亮相，电缆制造商 Precision Wires India 94 岁的创始人也首次亮相。大多数印度富人仍然来自孟买（328）、德里（199）和班加罗尔（100），分别是印度的商业、政治和科技之都。但今年又有 21 个城市跻身榜单，使得富豪居住的城市总数达到 95 个。

尽管许多印度富人仍然居住在国外，但大部分新资金都在国内。其中大部分也是实体经济的产物，而不是金融工程的产物。只有一位私募股权大亨上榜——Kedaara Capital 创始人曼尼什·凯杰里瓦尔 (Manish Kejriwal)，他的家族身家达 3.6 亿美元。在印度，最大的回报仍然属于建筑商而不是金融家。 ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 12:32:02 GMT /内容/18rjt5as3fc4nah0fu2gg4594vtneu3u https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/19/meet-indias-mega-wealthy Canon tries to break ASML’s grip on chipmaking tools

芯片制造工具的供应商很少引起人们的注意。然而，当佳能于 10 月 13 日推出一款新套件时，许多投资者的目光却发生了转变。很容易看出原因。这家制造光学设备的日本公司声称，其“纳米压印”光刻机可以蚀刻最先进微芯片中使用的最小晶体管。迄今为止，此类壮举一直是荷兰光刻工具制造商ASML的专利。佳能希望通过最终生产出两纳米芯片来进一步蚕食ASML的业务。

打破ASML对尖端芯片供应链的束缚的可能性令人着迷。该公司长期以来在集中的半导体行业享有最大的垄断地位。全球三大芯片制造商——英特尔、三星和台积电——完全依赖其极紫外 ( EUV ) 技术来生产用于智能手机和计算云所在的强大数据中心服务器的尖端微处理器。

ASML的EUV设备使用高功率激光器将电气蓝图蚀刻到圆形硅盘上。相比之下，佳能的替代方案是使用图案模具直接在此类晶圆上压印芯片设计。理论上，这使得它能够制作出更详细的图案。而且由于它涉及的步骤更少，并且不需要昂贵的激光器和超光滑镜子，因此它可能比EUV光刻便宜得多。受纳米压印消息影响， ASML股价下跌超过 2%，佳能股价上涨近 2%。

在实践中，佳能的工作还很艰巨。半导体研究公司 SemiAnalysis 的迪伦·帕特尔 (Dylan Patel) 指出，由于对齐晶圆和模具所需的精度，纳米压印光刻很容易出现缺陷。该技术在处理复杂的芯片设计方面也还不够有效，包括人工智能模型中使用的处理器，这些设计涉及多层化学沉积物。帕特尔先生预测，佳能的工具将用于制造层数较少的存储芯片部件，而不是用于处理信息而不是存储信息的高级“逻辑”芯片。

即使佳能能够克服所有这些技术障碍，芯片制造商也可能不愿意用其机器取代他们的EUV套件。芯片制造厂（简称晶圆厂）高度标准化，以最大程度地减少出现故障的芯片比例。由于ASML长期以来一直是尖端芯片领域的唯一竞争者，这种标准化意味着晶圆厂正在围绕其机器进行设计，这些机器的大小相当于双层巴士。芯片制造商目前在世界各地忙于建立的晶圆厂不会突然转向纳米压印光刻。研究公司 Gartner 的高拉夫·古普塔 (Gaurav Gupta) 认为，佳能的工具可能需要五年时间才能用于大规模生产，而且只有在它们证明了自己之后。

佳能可以更快取得进展的地方之一是中国。自2019年以来，中国企业一直受到美国出口管制的阻碍，无法购买ASML的EUV机器，因为它们都依赖于美国原产的零配件。它还在努力开发自己的光刻机。然而，美国目前的限制并未明确涵盖纳米压印技术。这使得佳能可以自由地将其出售给日本海对面的客户——至少暂时如此，也许会持续更长时间。目前还不清楚这家日本公司的机器是否包含足够的美国技术，以至于会受到美国的反华限制。也许没有人比华盛顿和北京的国家安全鹰派更对佳能的声明感到紧张了。 ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 12:32:02 GMT /内容/hvd0l73hhqsr9eui489pqn5octo53p28 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/19/canon-tries-to-break-asmls-grip-on-chipmaking-tools Why big oil is beefing up its trading arms

20世纪 50 年代，石油市场是“七姐妹”的恩赐。这些西方巨头公司控制着全球85%的原油储量，以及从油井到泵的整个生产过程。他们固定价格并瓜分市场。在氏族之外进行石油贸易几乎是不可能的。到了 20 世纪 70 年代，这种统治地位被彻底打破。阿拉伯石油禁运、波斯湾石油生产国有化以及嘉能可、维多和托克等海盗贸易公司的到来，导致姐妹党失去了影响力。到 1979 年，独立交易商负责世界五分之二的石油交易。

世界再次陷入动荡——不仅仅是因为以色列和哈马斯之间的冲突面临危险升级的风险。俄罗斯在乌克兰的战争、西方与中国之间的地缘政治紧张局势以及全球遏制气候变化的努力都断断续续地给石油市场带来了波动（见图1）。奥纬咨询 (Oliver Wyman) 的数据显示，在不确定时期蓬勃发展的大宗商品交易商的毛利润在 2022 年增长了 60%，达到 1150 亿美元。然而，这一次介入的并不是暴发户。而是七姐妹及其石油巨头的后裔，他们将贸易视为未来的重要组成部分。

这些公司不喜欢谈论他们的这部分业务。他们的交易员的利润隐藏在组织的其他部分。首席执行官们回避了刺探的问题。他们说，打开账本可能会向竞争对手泄露太多信息。但与分析师和业内人士的对话描绘了一幅庞大而复杂的业务的图景，而且这些业务的规模和复杂程度都在不断增长。

今年二月，美国最强大的超级巨头埃克森美孚公司在二十年前放弃了大规模交易，现在宣布将再次尝试。海湾国家的国营石油巨头也参与其中：沙特阿美公司、阿布扎比国家石油公司和卡塔尔能源公司正在扩大其交易业务，以跟上超级石油巨头的步伐。但贸易野心最为宏大的却是欧洲石油巨头。

Rystad Energy 咨询公司的 Jorge Léon 表示，自 2000 年代初以来，英国石油公司 (BP) 、壳牌公司和 TotalEnergies 一直在默默地扩大其交易平台。研究公司 Bernstein 估计，2023 年上半年，这三家公司的交易总计产生了 200 亿美元的毛利润。这比 2019 年同期增加了三分之二（见图 2），占总收入的五分之一，而四年前为七分之一。奥纬咨询估计，2016 年至 2022 年间，全球最大私营石油公司的交易员人数增加了 46%。其中大部分归功于欧洲三大石油公司。这些交易员中每一位的利润也比七年前增加了一倍半。

如今， BP在全球拥有 3,000 名交易员。据信，壳牌的交易员也有数千人，TotalEnergies 的交易员可能有 800 人。几乎可以肯定，这比托克 (Trafigura) 和维多 (Vitol) 等（同样羞涩的）独立交易商要多，后者的员工人数估计分别约为 1,200 人和 450 人（根据披露了作为公司股东的员工人数）。英国石油公司的交易主管卡罗尔·豪尔（Carol Howle）是该英国公司最高职位的领跑者，这可能并非巧合，该职位最近被伯纳德·鲁尼（Bernard Looney）空出。

超级巨头的交易台可能会在一段时间内保持忙碌，因为世界能源市场看起来不太可能平静下来。正如托克 (Trafigura) 的萨阿德·拉希姆 (Saad Rahim) 所说，“我们正在从大宗商品周期的世界转向大宗商品飙升的世界。”而这样的世界正是交易者的梦想。

波动加剧的原因之一是地缘政治冲突加剧。以色列和巴勒斯坦之间的冲突只是最新的例子。另一个是乌克兰战争。去年，欧盟因其侵略行为对其实施制裁后，俄罗斯停止向西输送天然气，对液化天然气（ LNG ）的需求猛增。欧洲超级大国的贸易部门也在急于填补这一缺口，并在此过程中大赚一笔。伯恩斯坦表示，去年他们从液化天然气交易中总共赚取了 150 亿美元，约占其交易利润的五分之二。

这可能只是一个开始。咨询公司麦肯锡最近的一份报告模拟了碳氢化合物区域贸易集团出现的情景。俄罗斯的燃料将向东流向中国、印度和土耳其，而不是向西流向欧洲。与此同时，中国正试图将海湾地区强大的生产商从美国及其盟友手中夺走。所有这些都为交易者创造了巨大的套利机会。

预计持续波动的另一个原因是气候变化。气温升高、海平面上升和极端天气的结合将更频繁地扰乱化石燃料的供应。 2021 年，德克萨斯州的一场寒流导致美国近 40% 的石油产量在两周内停产。风险咨询公司 Verisk Maplecroft 表示，全球约 30% 的石油和天然气储量面临类似气候破坏的“高风险”。

然后是能源转型，旨在避免更严重的极端气候。从长远来看，绿色能源系统很可能比当今基于化石燃料的能源系统波动性更小。它将更加分散，从而减少集中在世界不稳定地区的少数生产商手中。但从现在到气候友好型未来的道路充满了不确定性。

一些政府和激进股东正在向石油公司（尤其是欧洲石油公司）施压，要求其减少化石燃料押注。 Rystad Energy估计，部分原因是今年全球石油和天然气生产投资将达到5400亿美元，比2014年的峰值下降35%。与此同时，石油需求继续上升。 “这会给系统带来压力，”麦肯锡的罗兰·雷希斯坦纳 (Roland Rechtsteiner) 说。

未来交易者

这为交易者提供了机会，而不仅仅是石油领域。雷希施泰纳先生指出，对可再生能源进行大量投资而不同时增加输电容量也会造成瓶颈。彭博社NEF的一项研究称，在英国、意大利和西班牙，超过 150 吉瓦的风能和太阳能发电（相当于这三个国家现有可再生能源发电总量的 83%）无法并网，因为它们的电网无法处理。公司。交易者无法建立网格，但他们可以通过帮助将资源引导到最有利可图的用途来帮助缓解僵局。

欧洲三大石油巨头已经在经营电力和碳信用额，以及更多的天然气，天然气作为最不肮脏的化石燃料，被认为对能源转型至关重要。去年，进行此类交易的交易者数量是 2016 年的两倍。奥纬咨询 (Oliver Wyman) 的恩斯特·弗兰克尔 (Ernst Frankl) 估计，在此期间，他们产生的毛利润从 60 亿美元增至 300 亿美元。接下来可能会出现其他绿色商品。英国石油公司(BP)前交易主管、现就职于贝恩咨询公司的戴维·奈普 (David Knipe) 预计，一些大型企业将开始交易锂（一种用于电池制造的金属）。如果氢经济如许多石油巨头所希望的那样起飞，这将提供另一种东西，不仅可以生产，还可以买卖。 ■

; Thu, 19 Oct 2023 12:32:02 GMT /内容/jbpnoaqb6bu8hmg0d48hsdbr28pukk7e https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/19/why-big-oil-is-beefing-up-its-trading-arms Are America’s CEOs overpaid?

美国汽车工人联合会 ( UAW ) 老板肖恩·费恩 (Shawn Fain) 上个月在福特、通用汽车 ( GM ) 和斯特兰蒂斯 (Stellantis) 开始间歇性罢工后宣称： “我们已经厌倦了落后。”美国“三大”汽车制造商。一个月过去了，双方依然不和。福特首席执行官吉姆·法利 (Jim Farley) 辩称，罢工工人要求在四年内加薪 36%，这将削弱他的业务。 UAW反驳称，三大巨头首席执行官的平均薪酬比2019年高出40%，而工会成员的平均薪酬为6%，远低于通货膨胀率。去年，法利获得了 2100 万美元的薪酬，Stellantis 的卡洛斯·塔瓦雷斯 (Carlos Tavares) 获得了 2500 万美元，通用汽车公司的玛丽·巴拉 (Mary Barra) 获得了 2900 万美元。 UAW全职会员的平均收入不到 60,000 美元。 （Exor 是 Stellantis 的最大股东，部分拥有《经济学人》母公司。）

美国的老板们当然得到了丰厚的报酬。经过 2000 年代的低迷之后，标准普尔500 指数中大公司首席执行官的薪酬中位数在过去 10 年中攀升了 18%（考虑到通货膨胀因素），是美国全职工资中位数增幅的两倍。根据数据提供商 MyLog IQ的数据，标准普尔500 指数公司老板去年的收入超过 1400 万美元。这大约是普通工人的 250 倍。这也比英国老板的收入（富时 100指数公司的首席执行官的收入略低于 500 万美元）还要高，更不用说法国和德国了（这些国家首席执行官的薪酬还要低）。一些美国企业老总的收入是这个数字的好几倍。继 2019 年获得类似规模的赏金后， 科技巨头Alphabet 的桑达尔·皮查伊 (Sundar Pichai) 于 2022 年获得了 2.18 亿美元的股票奖励。2021 年，媒体巨头华纳兄弟探索公司 (Warner Bros Discovery) 的戴维·扎斯拉夫 (David Zaslav) 获得了价值估计为 2.03 亿美元的股票期权（主题达到某些性能障碍）。

就投资者而言，他们似乎并没有过度担心。据高管薪酬顾问 Meridian 称，去年，只有 4% 的标普500 指数公司未能在（不具约束力的）“薪酬发言权”投票中赢得多数支持。正如哈佛法学院的卢西恩·贝布丘克 (Lucian Bebchuk) 所解释的那样，美国的大型机构投资者很少关注整个市场的薪酬水平，而是关注CEO薪酬中与公司业绩挂钩的比例，以及他们的相对收入水平。给其他老板。代表养老基金和其他资产管理公司的机构投资者委员会的艾米·博勒斯表示，美国首席执行官的薪酬“太高了，我们已经对此麻木了”。然而，普通美国人却很愤怒。斯坦福大学的 David Larcker 和 Brian Tayan 在 2019 年进行的一项调查发现，86% 的人认为老板的薪酬过高。那么，是时候控制首席执行官的薪酬了吗？

其中一个考虑因素是基准应该是什么。伦敦商学院的亚历克斯·埃德曼斯指出，首席执行官并不是唯一拥有现金的群体。去年，勒布朗·詹姆斯通过投篮和代言球鞋赚取了 1.27 亿美元的收入。汤姆·克鲁斯凭借《壮志凌云：特立独行》的表演获得了 1 亿美元的收入。这些名人似乎并不比掌管着拥有数十亿美元资本和数万甚至数十万就业机会的大型公司的老板们更有价值。

与公司规模相比，老板们的薪酬看起来微不足道。去年标准普尔500指数公司首席执行官的总薪酬相当于该指数公司净利润的0.5%及其总市值的0.03%。投资者似乎相信一个好老板的价值是好几倍。 10月12日，美国折扣零售商Dollar General宣布，前任老板在继任者领导下业绩不佳后将重新掌舵。第二天，其股价上涨了 9%。美国大学的史蒂文·卡普兰 (Steven Kaplan) 认为，随着公司规模不断扩大（扣除通货膨胀因素后，标准普尔500 强公司去年的平均收入是 1990 年的两倍以上），并且更加全球化，首席执行官的工作也变得更加困难。芝加哥布斯商学院。

从欧洲的经验来看，减少老板的工资显然不是一个好主意。美国和欧洲老板之间的收入差距部分是由于欧洲高管竞争较少，因为欧洲大公司较少。它还反映出一种更加平等的薪酬态度，但这种态度并未转化为更好的绩效。欧洲公司的销售增长、盈利能力和股东回报率较低，员工的生产力也较低。所有这些都导致了非洲大陆经济增长缓慢。

今年早些时候，伦敦证券交易所(London Stock Exchange)主席朱莉娅·霍格特(Julia Hoggett)警告说，英国公司面临着因无法吸引高管人才而陷入困境的风险。去年，拉克斯曼·纳拉西姆汉 (Laxman Narasimhan) 放弃了在伦敦上市的消费品公司利洁时 (Reckitt Benckiser) 的最高职位，转而经营美国咖啡连锁店星巴克，从而使自己的薪酬翻了两番。在日本，首席执行官的薪酬甚至低于欧洲，丰田等公司已开始通过股票激励措施来提高薪酬方案。

贪婪是好的。正确的？

所有这些听起来都是一个令人信服的论据，支持让美国首席执行官摆脱丰厚报酬的束缚。但在实践中，股东应该注意两件事。其一，美国的首席执行官市场远非完美有效。许多老板在董事会中地位很高，可能会威胁到名义上独立的薪酬委员会。标准普尔500强公司的首席执行官中有五分之二还担任董事会主席。咨询公司普华永道最近对美国公司董事进行的一项调查显示，二分之一的人认为高管薪酬过高。当他们面对一位有血有肉的董事长时，他们在匿名调查中可能抱有的任何保留意见都会烟消云散。

更紧迫的担忧是，在普通民众处境艰难时向老板支付巨额费用，如果这鼓励员工提出公司无法承受的要求，可能会产生意想不到的后果。这种情况有可能发生在底特律，底特律必须在全球范围内与低成本汽车制造商竞争。换句话说， CEO的自由市场也受制于政治经济。 ■

; Tue, 17 Oct 2023 21:06:45 GMT /内容/hqii5l7f13431rkdesisbgclpcuojhpp https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/17/are-americas-ceos-overpaid Are America’s allies the holes in its export-control fence?

编者按（10 月 17 日）：本文针对美国对先进芯片出口管制的延伸进行了更新。

美国毫不掩饰地想要阻止其地缘政治霸权的独裁对手中国获得先进技术。 10 月 17 日，美国官员扩大了对用于训练人工智能 ( AI ) 模型的先进微芯片的销售限制。这是最新的一套出口管制措施，旨在阻止美国帮助创造的尖端技术（即目前的大部分技术）进入中国大陆。它还试图堵住一个漏洞，该漏洞允许中国公司的外国子公司采购其母公司被禁止购买的芯片。

几乎可以肯定，这个漏洞不是最后一个需要堵住的漏洞。就在本月，美国本身为更多人创造了空间。去年，它实施了全面的限制，切断了中国人和企业接触许多源自美国的先进技术的机会，包括各种尖端技术。 芯片、设计芯片的软件以及制造芯片的工具。 10 月 9 日，它授予两家韩国芯片制造商三星和SK海力士无限期豁免，允许他们在中国工厂安装受这些限制的设备。四天后，台湾芯片制造冠军台积电也获得了豁免。这些剥离是由首尔和台北政府确保（并宣布的），它们热衷于保护本国企业在中国的巨大商业利益。它们还揭示了美国领导的全球出口管制制度的棘手本质。

美国的全球制裁有赖于盟友的合作。原则上，亚洲和欧洲的民主政府同样对中国持谨慎态度，并正在制定自己的出口管制措施。实际上，他们的政策并不总是与山姆大叔的政策一致。结果可能是一系列规则，一旦实施，就会给科技公司带来成本，而不会像政权设计者所设想的那样对加强国家安全起到多大作用。

这并不是民主世界第一次试图阻止技术流向不民主的对手。第二次世界大战后，以美国为首的17个国家成立了多边出口管制协调委员会，限制向共产主义集团出口战略资源和技术。 1994 年，苏联的威胁不再存在后，该机构解散了。

迄今为止，美国协调一些反华限制措施的努力要零散得多。乔·拜登总统的政府最接近的协调是一月份与日本和荷兰签署的一项不透明协议。这对美国很重要，因为荷兰和日本公司（例如ASML和 Tokyo Electron）分别是精密芯片制造工具的唯一制造商，没有这些工具，几乎不可能生产最先进的半导体。 7月，日本政府出台了限制先进芯片技术出口的规定。 9 月份，荷兰同行也效仿了这一做法。

不过，仔细观察就会发现，这三个国家的出口管制的具体细节差异很大。美国出口管制机构工业与安全局（ BIS ）公布了一份包含数千家公司（其中包括大量中国公司）的“实体名单”，这些公司被禁止出售某些类型的技术。日本没有这样的公共实体清单。相反，它公布了 23 种需要出口许可证的特定产品类型的清单。日本政府刻意避免具体提及中国，以免激怒一个重要贸易伙伴。荷兰的控制措施也是“国家中立”的，并适用于少数产品。

不同国家的政权在其他方面存在着显着的差异。美国在欧洲和亚洲的盟友并没有试图效仿美国制裁的广泛、域外影响。因此，希望继续向中国客户出售技术的亚洲和欧洲公司理论上可以在没有严格出口管制的地方设立子公司（至少只要这些公司不依赖美国的投入）。

由于各国政府和欧盟之间的责任划分，欧洲的局势进一步复杂化。目前，个别欧盟成员国保留对其国家安全相关出口管制的自由裁量权。但鉴于欧盟的单一商品市场可以让技术不受阻碍地跨境流动，布鲁塞尔的欧盟官员希望拥有更大的发言权。

10 月 3 日，欧盟委员会提出了一份被认为对欧盟经济安全至关重要的领域清单。它希望能够在这些领域实施欧盟范围内的出口管制，其中包括先进芯片、量子计算和人工智能。目前尚不清楚 27 个欧盟成员国需要多长时间才能达成授予委员会此类权力所需的共识——如果能够达成的话。

当涉及到执行规则时，事情变得更加模糊。在大多数国家，监管出口管制制度的官僚能力有限。 America's BIS , widely considered to be better endowed than similar agencies in other countries, has fewer than 600 employees and an annual budget of just over $200m—a modest figure given the outfit's global remit. Its Asian and European counterparts must make do with far less.

The relevant agencies often lack the expertise to assess exporters' requests for a licence to sell products abroad. That requires an understanding of how a particular piece of equipment could be used. It is almost impossible to tell how such equipment will actually be employed once it arrives in China. This year the BIS set aside a relatively piddling sum of $6m for inspections to be conducted abroad—and little if any of this is likely to be spent on the Chinese mainland, where American inspectors are not exactly welcomed with open arms. Many of the BIS ’s poorer cousins in other countries depend wholly on the exporting businesses themselves to determine the actual end-use of their products, something the companies cannot know for sure either.

The result is a mishmash of opaque rules and fitful enforcement actions. Manufacturers of sensitive technologies are left guessing about what business they can and cannot do with Chinese firms. Four Taiwanese firms—Cica-Huntek Chemical Technology Taiwan, L & K Engineering, Topco Scientific and United Integrated Services—recently found themselves under investigation by Taiwan's government after reports surfaced that they were involved in building a new network of chip factories in China. The four companies all deny that they have broken any sanctions.

Lack of co-ordination may also explain why the system is not keeping high tech out of China as intended. In South Korea, SK Hynix is looking into how some of its older memory chips ended up in the latest smartphone made by Huawei. SK Hynix denies doing business with the Chinese telecoms giant. The Huawei smartphone in question, the Mate 60 Pro, also sported advanced microprocessors furnished by SMIC , China's biggest chip manufacturer. Both Huawei and SMIC feature on the BIS ’s entity list and were thought incapable of such chipmaking feats. Export comptrollers in America and its allies are still trying to work out how exactly the two companies pulled them off. This is unlikely to be the last China-related surprise they have to contend with. ■

; Mon, 16 Oct 2023 18:35:06 GMT /content/sa1am1ptsutss82am020dobpn9ij6rno https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/16/are-americas-allies-the-holes-in-its-export-control-fence A $3.8bn deal points to the future of car-parts suppliers

“I t's a good deal,” beams Klaus Rosenfeld, chief executive of Schaeffler, a maker of car parts based in Herzogenaurach, Bavaria. In the small hours of October 9th he called Andreas Wolf, his counterpart at Vitesco, a Bavarian rival, to offer to buy the 50.1% of the firm Schaeffler did not already own. The €3.6bn ($3.8bn) transaction, says Mr Rosenfeld, will create a competitive German giant in an industry undergoing a huge shift to electric cars.

Schaeffler last attempted a big takeover in 2008, when it won a controlling stake in Continental, a rival then three times its size. That deal, financed entirely by debt, almost sank the family-owned business. This time the transaction is smaller—Vitesco, which was itself spun off from Continental in 2021, has annual sales of €9bn, compared with €16bn for Schaeffler. The merger also relies less on borrowed money. And Mr Rosenfeld, who became Schaeffler's boss in 2014 and took the company public a year later, is a banker by training and cautious by temperament.

The acquisition is expected to produce cost savings of around €500m a year. It will also simplify Schaeffler's shareholder structure, increase its transparency and make Schaeffler shares easier to trade. As part of the deal the Schaeffler family has agreed to give up its monopoly on voting shares (though it will remain firmly in control, with a 75% stake in the new firm). Most important, the transaction will create a global car-parts behemoth, with 120,000 staff worldwide.

In order to thrive in the era of electric vehicles ( EV s), the car-parts industry needs to consolidate. Electric cars require many fewer components than those equipped with internal-combustion engines ( ICE s), so economies of scale matter all the more. The deal will certainly shore up Schaeffler's position in the EV business, says Marc-René Tonn of Warburg, a German bank. Vitesco is a big supplier of electric motors and electronics for EV s. It received orders of more than €10bn for such EV parts in 2022, twice as much as Schaeffler, and expects a similar amount this year.

The merged company nevertheless faces challenges. Despite rising EV -linked orders, ICE -related parts such as powertrains and chassis account for roughly 40% of Schaeffler's annual sales and 80% of Vitesco's. Both companies rely heavily on China. Schaeffler has 13,000 staff and 13 factories in China. The vast Chinese market also accounts for 23% of its sales. Vitesco, which has around 6,500 people in four Chinese factories, derives 15% of revenue from the country.

Mr Rosenfeld thinks that, far from being a geopolitical liability at a time of rising Sino-Western tensions, the Chinese ties could be a commercial asset. The deal, he says, “will help us with our Chinese business”. These involve more than just car parts; Schaeffler's Chinese factories also make bearing systems for aeroplanes and wind turbines. Moreover, good relations with Chinese carmakers are important for another reason. When China's ambitious manufacturers of electric cars set up factories in Europe, they will need local suppliers. Schaeffler looks well positioned to be one of them. ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 14:04:45 GMT /content/kms15b231qsikbc4bf2it6d3ljjngs12 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/12/a-38bn-deal-points-to-the-future-of-car-parts-suppliers The fall of China’s “manganese king” may hit global EV supply chains

O NE AFTER another, the empires of China's most powerful industrialists are collapsing. In January local media reported that Li Hejun, a solar-panel magnate and once the country's richest man, had been detained by the police. Liu Zhongtian, who created Asia's largest aluminium company, is said to have been chased by creditors this year as his company is restructured. Hui Ka Yan, another erstwhile rich-list-topper, was detained in September as his property-development group, Evergrande, foundered. On October 10th Bloomberg reported that He Jinbi, the boss of one of China's largest copper-trading houses, had also been apprehended by the authorities.

Against this backdrop, the troubles of Jia Tianjiang, a 61-year-old billionaire who built a global manganese empire, may seem unremarkable. On September 22nd a Chinese court put his company, Tianyuan Manganese Industry ( TMI ), into administration, after the huge debts Mr Jia accrued had gone unpaid. Yet his predicament may have consequences far beyond his business—and beyond China's borders. That is because manganese is used to make types of high-quality steel and in lithium-ion batteries, both of which are instrumental to supply chains President Xi Jinping views as strategic. And Mr Jia, widely known in China as “Manganese King”, has been instrumental in the metal's production.

Mr Jia is the classic rags-to-riches story. One of 13 siblings from a poor town in China's north-west, he got his start by selling apples on the street. Later he sold the cardboard used to package the apples and eventually opened his own cardboard factory. In 2003 he bought a failed manganese mine just as China's homebuilding boom began. This eventually made him the richest man in Ningxia province, where his company is based.

In the 2010s Mr Jia began diversifying into finance and moving capital offshore. He bought large stakes in several Hong Kong-based investment groups with the help of a friend, Lai Xiaomin, the financier behind Huarong, a state-owned asset manager. In 2017 Mr Jia was, to many observers' surprise, allowed to buy a 20% stake in China Citic Bank International, the Hong Kong banking arm of one of China's mightiest state conglomerates.

The same year he used state-backed loans to purchase one of the world's largest manganese miners, Consolidated Minerals, from a Ukrainian billionaire. Mr Jia then secured a $450m loan from a Citic subsidiary using Consolidated Minerals, which at the time had a net asset value of just $235m, as collateral.

Mr Jia's expansion plans began to unravel in 2018, when Lai was detained for financial crimes. Rumours of TMI ’s financial connections to Lai were enough to send the price of one type of refined manganese soaring. The value of many of Mr Jia's companies collapsed. He was ensnared in an investigation but subsequently released. (Lai was less lucky: he was executed in 2021.) At the time executives working for the company in Europe feared his troubles at home might spill into global markets.

Now they have. “This is like Rio Tinto going bust for the iron-ore industry,” says one mining executive, referring to the Anglo-Australian mining giant. A bigger shock could affect the production of lithium-ion batteries. High-purity manganese sulphate is commonly used to make battery cathodes. Production of the material is part of China's plan to dominate the global battery industry. In 2022 the state-run China Energy Engineering Corporation launched a project with a TMI subsidiary that planned eventually to produce 1m tonnes of high-purity manganese sulphate annually. That would have made TMI the biggest producer in the world.

This makes it unlikely that TMI will be allowed to buckle. Still, disruptions to domestic and global supply of the metal seem inevitable, making the state's target for high-purity manganese sulphate look optimistic. Mr Jia is not Lai. He is not accused of any crimes. But to the Chinese state the Manganese King must look like an unreliable strategic ally. ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 14:04:45 GMT /content/s5dq8jj77bu4amsskuc1h77l3cmfh03e https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/12/the-fall-of-chinas-manganese-king-may-hit-global-ev-supply-chains Trialling the two-day workweek

W e have completed our pilot of the two-day workweek, and present our findings below. We would like to thank the leadership team for being imaginative enough to allow this experiment. We are also very sorry.

Background: We are consistently looking for ways to stand out as an employer of choice. Recent trials of the four-day workweek at other companies suggest that there might be ways to improve work-life balance and satisfaction without hurting productivity. Our former head of HR , Joe King, pushed us to be bolder. If people were able to fit a whole week into four days, was it possible to go further still? The idea to trial a two-day workweek in our North American territory was born. And to reiterate the point above, you all agreed to this.

Outline of the trial: Employees began work at 9am on a Monday as usual. They did a 20-hour shift until early Tuesday morning, and then had an eight-hour break, before beginning a second 20-hour shift. The workweek ended at 9am on Wednesday morning, at which point employees took the next five days off and returned the following Monday.

To make things simple, all employees in the region were opted into this new arrangement. Regrettably, we quickly lost all colleagues who were single parents, and many other employees with young children. Some legal action is continuing as a result. But the initial response from those who remained was extremely positive.

Results of the trial: It immediately became clear that most people were unable to stay awake during either shift without needing some kind of stimulant. A few members of the marketing team remained extremely animated throughout their shifts; as you know, the early-morning cleaners later reported that they had come across three of them snorting cocaine off the reception desk. In later weeks we invested in various options to keep staff pepped up, including energy drinks, guarana powder and free M & M ’s. We also provided sleeping bags for people to grab power naps.

The extent of other problems became clearer as the pilot proceeded. Customers who tried to reach us outside our new working hours were told to contact us again at 9am on the following Monday. We saw enormous call waiting-times at the start of each week. In one case, a customer was told they would be on hold for an estimated 49 hours, putting them outside the window of that workweek, too. We attracted a lot of criticism for this on social media, though none of us noticed.

The rush to get everything done in two days caused other problems. Our suppliers were not always able to deliver while staff were on duty, leading to production bottlenecks. We made a lot more basic mistakes: the payroll snafu in August happened partly because our finance director's power nap turned into something closer to a hibernation. We struggled to get activities like recruitment done in the time available to us. Our sales team found that most clients were unwilling to meet after midnight. Shorter workweeks are known to pose co-ordination issues. Such problems are soluble in some conditions, but not these ones.

The benefits of a better work-life balance were also less great than we had hoped. The demands of shift work during those first two days meant that some team members took four or five days to recover from the workweek. Many employees completely lost track of time during their “workends” and failed to turn up on Monday mornings, making it even harder to manage the rush at the start of the week.

Cohesion suffered, particularly after a brawl broke out among the graphic designers one week for the last remaining energy drinks. Appetite for team-building activities also declined; in retrospect, holding end-of-the-week drinks at sunrise on Wednesdays was unwise. Our apologies again to the cleaners.

During the course of the trial we saw marked declines in almost all the metrics we tracked, from sales revenue and net promoter scores to productivity and employee satisfaction. There were some exceptions to this trend. We saw sharp rises in customer complaints, health-and-safety incidents, substance abuse and tooth decay.

Recommendations: We do not recommend a repeat of this experiment (this may be academic since the North American business is now closing down). If creativity is a willingness to take immensely stupid risks, we can all look back on this episode with pride. On any other definition, we cannot. ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 14:04:45 GMT /content/d9sk44t7q84flauajuu1tlu4gork0aie https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/12/trialling-the-two-day-workweek Why young consumers love Birkenstocks

I N THE BLOCKBUSTER “Barbie” film, the Birkenstock is more than a shoe. It is a symbol of the real world not run by girls. It is introduced as a deliberately drab antithesis of Barbie's perfect stiletto. By the film's end the titular blonde is wearing the cork sandal—with the hallmark double-strap in her signature pink—as she walks into her new life, no longer a doll but a woman ready to put her best foot forward.

Barbie is not the only one swapping heels for contoured soles. So are real-life youngsters. Birkenstock's revenues have doubled in the past three years, to $1.4bn. Almost half of last year's sales came courtesy of buyers in their 20s and 30s. Some of that is down to clever product placement—social-media mentions of Birkenstocks reached a record high in July around the time of the “Barbie” premiere. A lot more has to do with a post-pandemic fashion for all things casual and comfortable, especially among Millennials and Gen-Zs, which has boosted sales of other ungainly casual-chic footwear, such as furry Ugg boots or Croc sandals.

What is cool with the kids proved hot with some investors. On October 10th Birkenstock raised $1.5bn in an initial public offering ( IPO ) on the New York Stock Exchange, valuing the firm at around $9bn.

Although Birkenstocks are far from beautiful—German children forced to wear them to school in the 1980s bemoaned their ugliness—their maker has managed to turn itself into an aspirational brand. It has collaborated with Dior, a high-fashion brand controlled by LVMH , a French luxury behemoth, to make $1,100 mules. It probably helped that L Catterton, a private-equity firm which bought a majority stake in 2021, is backed by LVMH . The family holding company of LVMH ’s boss, Bernard Arnault, said it would buy up to $325m-worth of Birkenstock shares in the IPO and nominate one of Mr Arnault's sons to its board.

Perhaps owing to the influence of its luxury backers, Birkenstock has no plans to increase production capacity; ever since Johann Adam Birkenstock started making shoes in 1774, the company has insisted on maintaining almost all its production in Germany (only some of the cork soles are made in Portugal). Engineering scarcity by limiting output is a time-honoured strategy for high-end brands that peddle exclusivity. Their couture-pocketed customers tend to be insensitive to price rises.

Birkenstock has managed to push up prices a bit in the past few years, but revenue growth also came from increased shipments. It is unclear how much more expensive it can make its sandals without putting off its customers. Investors are already watching their step. Its share price slipped by 13% on its first day of trading. ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 14:04:45 GMT /content/0km7u2p3q05bqamr8j08jm90h0stff7c https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/12/why-young-consumers-love-birkenstocks Taiwan will not surrender its semiconductor supremacy

F ROM the 1970s until a few years ago Taiwan's semiconductor sector looked worthy but dull. Its chip-fabrication plants (fabs for short) kept the global electronics industry ticking, but it was the gadgets the chips went into that made headlines.

No longer. The world's geopolitical heavyweights now regard microprocessors as powering not just all manner of machines but their economies as well. America is splurging $50bn in subsidies to bring chipmaking back home. Europe has similar plans, not least to reduce its dependence on Taiwan, which next-door China claims as part of its territory. Rapidus, a joint venture of Japanese electronics firms, aims to be mass-producing cutting-edge chips by 2027, just two years after TSMC , the Taiwanese chip champion, will start manufacturing similar silicon. Samsung of South Korea, TSMC ’s main rival, hopes to begin churning out such chips in 2025. China, for its part, wants to build an independent chip industry that does not have to rely on imports of technology, which America is choking off.

The stakes for Taiwan are high. So long as everyone relies on the island for semiconductors, the thinking goes, not even China will up-end the geopolitical status quo. If chips are made elsewhere, this “silicon shield” turns brittle. More prosaically, the sector, with eight of the country's ten best-paying companies, provides good jobs. Taiwanese chip firms also have reasons to keep production at home. Too much expansion abroad could weaken local research networks and make it easier for foreign firms to poach staff.

This explains why TSMC ’s subsidised fabs in America will not be at the technological frontier by the time they are completed in 2025 and 2026. The cutting-edge will remain at home. Last year TSMC spent about $5bn on research and development ( R & D ), 30% more than in 2021, and most of it in Taiwan. In July this year, the company opened a new R & D centre for 7,000 staff next to its headquarters in Hsinchu. As long as R & D is done at home, the chipmakers' most advanced fabs will probably remain there, too.

Taiwanese firms in other bits of the supply chain are making similar calculations. ASE Holdings is the world's largest chip packager. Putting processors in a casing used to be an unglamorous business. As it becomes harder to shrink transistors to less than the current few billionths of a metre across, firms like ASE can help boost processing power with c lever packages that connect chips to one another. ASE ’s annual R & D budget more than doubled between 2017 and 2022, to $800m. As with TSMC , much of that will stay in Taiwan.

Taiwan's government also remains intent on maintaining the country's chip supremacy. It has long suppressed the value of the Taiwanese dollar, which supports exports, including of chips, and subsidised the prices of energy and water, both of which chipmakers guzzle. Morris Chang, TSMC ’s retired co-founder, intimated last month that even Taiwan's high-speed rail network may have been designed with chipmaking in mind, to let workers zip between production sites.

The government's latest plan is to shore up Taiwanese chip design, part of the industry dominated by American companies like AMD and Nvidia. MediaTek, Taiwan's biggest designer, ranks a lowly (by Taiwanese chip standards) fifth in the world in terms of blueprint sales. The firm would no doubt love to move up in the ranking, and the government seems eager to help it with an aim to raise Taiwan's share of global chip-design revenues from 21% to 40%. Last month the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced a modest $25m in subsidies to help small and middling semiconductor firms designing less advanced chips. More goodies will be included in the government's next ten-year plan for the chip industry, due next year. Taiwan won't give up its shield without a fight. ■
